Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Psychological Difficulties and Benefits of Deliberative Reflection

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to occupy ourselves solely with our thoughts, paying no attention to the external world, is one of the signatures of what it is to be human. Although there is substantial research on many forms of reflection, such as problem solving and planning, there is relatively little research on deliberate attempts to improve one's subjective well being with one's own thoughts in the absence of any external stimulation. On the one hand this would seem easy to do so, given the richness of human memory (e.g., the ability to recall pleasant events from one's past) and the ability to construct enjoyable daydreams and fantasies. On the other hand, people do not often choose to entertain themselves solely with their minds. When at home with nothing to do, for example, most people choose to read, watch television, listen to music, or pursue their favorite hobby instead of engaging in reflection. The proposed research will investigate why this is, the conditions under which people can put their disengaged minds to good use, and the benefits of deliberative reflection. The overall goal of the research is to understand better the nature of human attention and mental control, and by so doing, discover new ways in which people can reduce stress and improve their well-being.

In preliminary research, Timothy Wilson (University of Virginia), Daniel Gilbert (Harvard University) and colleagues found that people typically do not enjoy spending time by themselves with nothing to do but think, that they enjoyed doing mundane external activities much more, and that many preferred to administer electric shocks to themselves instead of being left alone with their thoughts. Most people seem to prefer to be doing something rather than nothing, even if that something is negative. The proposed research will investigate three possible reasons why this is. First, if people attempt to think exclusively about positive thoughts for too long, negative thoughts begin to intrude. Second, in the absence of any external stimulation people continually scan the external environment. If there is nothing in the external world to engage the scanner it keeps searching for input, using up resources that could be devoted to internal thought. Third, people may not know how to engage in reverie effectively but can be taught to do so. The 12 proposed studies will involve laboratory experiments, field experiments, and experience sampling methodologies, and include college students and community members as participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to occupy oneself solely with one’s thoughts, paying no attention to the external world, has been lauded throughout human history and is one of the signatures of what it is to be human. Although there is substantial research on many forms of reflection, such as problem solving and planning, there is relatively little research on deliberate attempts to improve one’s subjective well-being with one’s own thoughts in the absence of any external stimulation. The question is, can people retreat into their own minds to reduce stress? Are there other benefits of “thinking for pleasure”? For example, is it an antidote to “device obsession,” the increasing tendency for people to spend their time on electronic devices?

Our initial research showed that people did not attempt to think for pleasure very often and did not enjoy it very much when they tried to do so. One study, for example, found that people throughout the world (in 11 different countries) enjoying doing everyday external tasks, such as playing with their phones, more than “just thinking.” By understanding why this is, we have succeeded in finding ways in which people can succeed in thinking for pleasure. We argue that enjoying one’s thoughts is like any cognitive skill that requires both ability and motivation. By ability we mean having the cognitive resources to maintain a stream of enjoyable thought, which involves selecting a topic, deciding how long to think about it, monitoring for the intrusion of unwanted thoughts, deciding when to switch topics, and so on. By motivation we mean that people have to be willing to exert the effort to enjoy their own thoughts. We found in several studies that people enjoy their thoughts more when the task is made easier and people are motivated to do it. For example, people enjoyed their thoughts more when given a simple “thinking aid,” in which they first generated a list of pleasurable topics and then were reminded of those topics while engaging in thinking.

Can people succeed in thinking for pleasure in their everyday lives, instead of relying so heavily on electronic devices? We conducted a field study in which people were randomly assigned to spend spare moments of their day enjoying their thoughts or doing what they normally do (which turned out to be mostly time spent on their phones and other devices). Those randomly assigned to put their phones aside and enjoy their thoughts enjoyed their spare moments somewhat more. Importantly, they also found thinking to be a much more personally meaningful experience than engaging in their normal spare time activities. There is more to learn about how and when this technique works, but we have made substantial progress in showing that people can use their own thoughts to reduce stress, improve their moods, and increase a sense of meaning in their lives.
